occurrences.line_text: By forged treason, or by open fight
He now this Ladies champion chose for loue to fight.
Where when as two braue knights in bloudy fight
In cruell fight on lybicke Ocean wide,
But still when Guyon came to part their fight,
Straunge sort of fight, three valiaunt knights to see
Of armes was wont to fight, yet nathemoe
And stirre him vp to strife and cruell fight.
For he is all disposd to bloudy fight,
With silly weake old woman thus to fight.
Pyrrochles does with Guyon fight,
On foot with him to matchen equall fight;
That he would algates with Pyrrochles fight,
From needlesse trouble of renewing fight
And glorious spoiles, purchast in perilous fight:
And called for his armes; for he would algates fight.
Nor care of vow'd reuenge, and cruell fight,
Disdeigning to be held so long in fight;
And sith for me ye fight, to me this grace
But if for me ye fight, or me will serue,
To proue extremities of bloudie fight,
And counseld him abstaine from perilous fight:
They for vs fight, they watch and dewly ward,
The same to thee, against his lord to fight,
Or did he fall by treason, or by fight?
Wanting his sword, when he on foot should fight:
Had reard himselfe againe to cruell fight,
So did Sir Guyon[Prince Arthur] beare himselfe in fight,
And were enraunged ready, still for fight.
He them defeated in victorious fight,
Made warre on him, and fell him selfe in fight:
Yet ceased not the bloudy fight for ought;
And yet though ouercome in haplesse fight,
The Romane legion in dreadfull fight:
To see a cruell fight doen by the Prince this day.
Against that same fift bulwarke they continued fight.
For her defence, against that Carle to fight,
When as the Russian him in fight does chace)
But freshly as at first, prepard himselfe to fight.
Against this lifelesse shadow so to fight:
Rather for pleasure, then for battery or fight.
The martiall brood accustomed to fight:
That for his trusty seruaunts doth so strongly fight.
Or euer hope to match in equall fight,
Against his Saxon foes in bloudy field to fight.
Thrise shall he fight with them, and twise shall win,
Beside Cayr Verolame, in victorious fight,
No whit lesse faire, then terrible in fight:
But more that with his foes he could not come to fight.
As euer man that bloudy field did fight;
Her selfe to fight addrest, and threw her lode aside.
So ran the Geauntesse vnto the fight;
She turnd, and semblaunce of faire fight did make;
Ne any may that Monster match in fight,
But Paridell complaynd, that his late fight
And how we with our foe may come to fight.
Their fight and warlike deedes.
In perilous fight, she neuer ioyed day,
A perilous fight when he with force her brought
Ne list I for reuenge prouoke new fight,
That through the bruses of his former fight,
Your selfe for this, my selfe will for you fight,
Or answere for thy wrong, as shall fall out in fight.
With murdrous weapons arm'd to cruell fight,
Bidding them fight for honour of their loue,
There they I weene would fight vntill this day,
That none of them durst vndertake the fight;
On horsebacke vsed Triamond to fight,
For Canacee with Cambell for to fight:
Right practicke was Sir Priamond in fight,
Who him affronting soone to fight was readie prest.
Could stand on foot, now to renew the fight.
And fiercely each assayling, gan afresh to fight.
And eft them turned both againe to fight;
But that he yet was sore of his late lucklesse fight.
Yee shall her winne, as I haue done in fight:
His person to emperill so in fight.
When who so list to fight, may fight his fill,
When who so list to fight, may fight his fill,
That none could him discerne, and so went forth to fight.
Approued oft in many a perlous fight.
That bore the Hebene speare, as wonne in fight.
Some proffer made with him for her to fight.
Doe fight with Britomart:
Whiles with long fight on foot he breathlesse was,
Through toylesome heate and labour of her weary fight.
But when in vaine to fight she oft assayd,
Hath conquered you anew in second fight:
Thereto the villaine vsed craft in fight;
And if it chaunst, (as needs it must in fight)
Whom yet he conquer'd not by bloudie fight,
So all afresh gan former fight renew.
Thus they long while continued in fight,
In open turney, and by wrongfull fight
To fight with Hercules, that did aduance
His dreadfull heast, much lesse him match in fight,
Since he himselfe it vs'd in that great fight
Or else by ordele, or by blooddy fight;
Does with the Pagan fight:
For on a Bridge he custometh to fight,
And streight him selfe vnto the fight addrest,
To fight in water, great aduantage had,
All sixe well seene in armes, and prou'd in many a fight.
And there all day continew'd cruell fight,
For which he chalenged the thiefe to fight.
With weapons in their hands, as ready for to fight.
Beholding all that womanish weake fight;
For being ouercome by her in fight,
But ere she could ioyne hand with him to fight,
But mongst the rest the fight did vntill euening last.
Causd all her people to surcease from fight,
There she resolu'd her selfe in single fight
Tell, that to morrow I with him will fight,
That he mote fresher be against the next daies fight.
The last daies purpose of their vowed fight,
Her to receiue, till time they should begin the fight.
In stead of Curiets and bases fit for fight.
Her vassall to become, if she him wonne in fight.
To fight with him, and goodly die her last:
Since that he was not forst, nor ouercome in fight?
Two Knights, all armed ready for to fight,
On which Pollente with Artegall did fight.
Did forth issue, all ready for the fight:
Whilest Fortune fauourd her successe in fight,
To Iustice, and against her still doth fight,
In the behalfe of wronged weake did fight:
for Belgee for to fight:
And th'armes and legs of three, to succour him in fight.
But Hercules them all did ouercome in fight.
And vanquished all ventrous knights in fight;
And gan with courage fierce addresse him to the fight.
Gerioneo in fight:
And gan him selfe to fight on foote prepare.
Tho when she saw, that she was forst to fight,
With her vnrighteous enemy to fight,
Who when he gaue me armes, in field to fight,
And buckling him eftsoones vnto the fight,
Of fayre Irenaes cause with him in single fight.
With which he wont to fight, to iustifie his wrong.
Thereto he had great skill in single fight:
But gan him streight to buckle to the fight,
But Calidore, that was well skild in fight,
Hauing late slaine her Seneschall in fight,
And passing well expert in single fight,
And proue the finall fortune of the fight:
How euer strong and fortunate in fight,
Himselfe to yeeld his loue, or else to fight.
These goodly gilden armes, which I haue won in fight.
For he durst not abide with Calidore to fight.
To iustifie thy fault gainst me in equall fight.
Vnlesse that with his Lord he formerly did fight.
Yet if he needes will fight, craue leaue till morne,
Yet armes or weapon had he none to fight,
And proued oft in many perillous fight,
Through many wounds, which lately he in fight
To fight with many foes about him ment,
A wrongfull quarrell to maintaine by fight;
By this quite slaine in so vnequall fight:
Who notwithstanding that in former fight
Which neuer yet they had approu'd in fight;
Himselfe recouering, was return'd to fight;
Wearie of trauell in his former fight,
With such huge strokes, approued oft in fight,
Gan all vpon him lay: there gan a dreadfull fight.
Britomart fightes with many Knights,
Was he abashed now not fighting so,
So wearie both of fighting had their fill,
That forced them from fighting to refraine,
Fighting on foot, as well he him descryde,
The knight with that old Dragon fights
Fights with Cymochles, whiles his bro-
And this braue knight, that for that vertue fights,
Artegall fights with Radigund
She fights with Radigund, her slaies,
He with the great Grantorto fights,
Had deathes owne image figurd in her face,
Cannot your glorious pourtraict figure plaine
Yet could not find what sence it figured:
Now turned into figures hideous,
Figuring straunge characters of his art,
For hauing filcht her bels, her vp he cast
Which lewdnesse fild him with reprochfull paine
Their mournefull charet, fild with rusty blood,
And fild far landes with glorie of his might,
And stony horrour all her sences fild
And fild her hidden caues with stormie yre,
Puft vp with emptie wind, and fild with sinfull crime.
And at him fiercely flew, with courage fild,
With wine and water fild vp to the hight,
And thrise three times had fild her crooked hornes,
But that the foolish man, fild with delight
With false delights, and fild with pleasures vaine,
Did feed his eyes, and fild his inner thought.
For with all shame that sacred throne he fild:
That groueling to the ground he fell, and fild his place.
About them flew, and fild their sayles with feare:
Of hungry eies, which n'ote therewith be fild,
Vile rancour their rude harts had fild with such despight.
And fild his senses with abashment great;
Ensewd, whose noyance fild the fearefull sted,
He fild with Hylas name; the Nymphes eke Hylas cryde.
Being thereof beguyld was fild with new affright.
Fild with false rumors and seditious trouble,
That fild the lookers on attonce with ruth and wonder.
Streight entring into Triamond, him fild
Had fild, that he to fell reueng was fully bent.
And all his hairy brest with gory bloud was fild.
Her noble heart with sight thereof was fild
And inward grudge fild his heroicke brest:
Which all the world haue with their issue fild?
That Proteus house they fild euen to the dore;
And fild his ballaunce full of idle toys:
Whereat her heart was fild with hope and drede;
So fild with heauenly fury, thus he her behight.
But fild with courage and with ioyous glee,
Was fild with bloud, which from their sides did flow,
Was stretched forth, that nigh fild all the place,
With great amazement, & his thought with wonder fild.
And well could file his tongue as smooth as glas;
And thus replide, How euer, Sir, ye file
His practick wit, and his faire filed tong,
She lightly lept out of her filed bed,
Arriued there, the little house they fill,
Full enuious that night so long his roome did fill.
And when they both had wept and wayld their fill,
He now Lord of the field, his pride to fill,
To fill his bags, and richesse to compare;
And thousands moe the like, that did that dongeon fill.
Conceiueth fire, the heauens it doth fill
And fill the fields with troublous bellowing,
That ay thereof her babes might sucke their fill;
Those glistring armes, that heauen with light did fill,
That all the ayre about with smoke and stench did fill.
And mortall arrowes, wherewith he doth fill
And gazing wonder they their minds did fill;
Which him before, that sacred seate did fill,
And to the brim with Colt wood did it fill,
And Bangor with massacred Martyrs fill;
Thus when they all had sorrowed their fill,
He loued, and at last her wombe did fill
Possesseth him, and of his sweetnesse takes her fill.
To fill his hellish gorge, it chaunst a knight
Her garments gay with scales of fish, that all did fill.
On her faire face so did he feede his fill,
Now when of meats and drinks they had their fill,
Which all the forrest did with horror fill:
I saw him sleepe with her all night his fill,
And when at last she had beheld her fill,
So wearie both of fighting had their fill,
When who so list to fight, may fight his fill,
But thus brake forth, that all the temple it did fill.
Who all that comes doth take, and therewith fill
To fill the other scale with so much wrong.
The sight whereof did all with gladnesse fill:
But thought, that she thereon could neuer gaze her fill.
That all the Temple did with terrour fill;
Ere he had slept his fill, he wakened were,
And all the woods with piteous plaints did fill,
Vse scanted diet, and forbeare your fill,
Sleepe out her fill, without encomberment:
Confused, did the ayre with terror fill,
Tho hauing fed his fill, he there besyde
And there by her were poured forth at fill,
That all the ayre with terrour filled wide,
And all the chamber filled was with flyes,
That all their senses filled with affright,
Stood gazing, filled were with rufull tine,
And filled all the house with feare and great vprore.
And filles with flowres faire Floraes painted lap:
That furthest Nations filles with awfull dread,
From her faire head her fillet she vndight,
And piteous plaints she filleth his dull eares,
That filleth all the sea with fome, diuydes
One with great bellowes gathered filling aire,
That all the aire it fils, and flyes to heauen bright.
Long fostred in the filth of Lerna lake,
Whose secret filth good manners biddeth not be told.
Their bloud with secret filth infected hath,
Ne lets her waues with any filth be dyde,
The flood of drops, the Monster filth did breede:
But sparks, seed, drops, and filth do thus delay;
The drops dry vp, and filth wipe cleane away:
That all the bloud and filth away was washt,
But mucky filth his braunching armes annoyes,
Delights in filth and foule incontinence:
Into all filth and foule iniquitie,
Most vgly filth, and poyson therewith rusht,
And from his face the filth that did it ray,
Thereto approch, ne filth mote therein drowne:
In which what filth and ordure did appeare,
Most lothsom, filthie, foule, and full of vile disdaine.
That from her body full of filthie sin
Deformed creature, on a filthie swyne,
That breathed euer forth a filthie banefull smell.
And fingers filthie, with long nayles vnpared,
Most foule and filthie were, their garments yet
Which vnderneath did hide his filthinesse,
To hide her shame and loathly filthinesse;
They held this land, and with their filthinesse
Therewith she spewd out of her filthy maw
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
A filthy foule old woman I did vew,
Who rough, and blacke, and filthy did appeare,
At her abhorred face, so filthy and so fowle.
A monstrous beast ybred in filthy fen
And vnderneath his filthy feet did tread
That her gay garments staynd with filthy gore,
But all the floore (too filthy to be told)
But neither darkenesse fowle, nor filthy bands,
Was ouergrowne with scurfe and filthy scald;
Hong downe, and filthy matter from them weld;
And all her filthy feature open showne,
The filthy blots of sinne to wash away.
Enwrapt in coleblacke clouds and filthy smoke,
Layd first his filthy hands on virgin cleene,
Gan burne in filthy lust, and leaping light,
In ragged robes, and filthy disaray,
Whose glistring glosse darkned with filthy dust,
But both his hands most filthy feculent,
Where companing with feends and filthy Sprights,
Of filthy lust, contrarie vnto kind:
In brutish minds, and filthy lust inflame,
Of filthy wretch? well may shee you reproue
Ruffled and fowly raid with filthy soyle,
And out of that same fishers filthy nest
A filthy bloud, or humour rancorous,
And filthy lust exceede all woman kind,
Her face most fowle and filthy was to see,
His mighty limbs, whilest all with filthy bloud
With filthy lockes about her scattered wide,
Whose waters with his filthy bloud it stayned:
In filthy durt, and left so in the loathely soyle.
Through fowle commixture of his filthy blot;
Vnmard with ragged mosse or filthy mud;
At last resolu'd to worke his finall smart,
His life, and long good fortune vnto finall fate.
To bring her backe againe, or worke her finall bale.
Of finall peace and faire attonement,
He should his flale to finall execution bend.
So that with finall force them all he ouercame.
And proue the finall fortune of the fight:
It neuer rests, till it haue wrought his finall bane.
That monstrous Beast by finall force to quell,
Should fetch againe, and finally destroy
Then forth I went his woefull corse to find,
O how, said he, mote I that well out find,
How does he find in cruell hart to hate
And all that he by right or wrong could find,
Was writ Sans ioy, they new arriued find:
Scarse could he footing find in that fowle way,
Yet crime in her could neuer creature find,
There find the virgin dolefull desolate,
And henceforth nothing faire, but her on earth they find.
A Satyre chaunst her wandring for to find,
Go find some other play-fellowes, mine own sweet boy.
Or liking find to gaze on earthly mould,
She vp arose, resoluing him to find
If then it find not helpe, and breedes despaire.
There for to find a fresh vnproued knight,
But no where could he find that wofull thrall:
Where entred in, his foot could find no flore,
Could euer find, to grieue the gentlest hart on ground?
And neuer vow to rest, till her I find,
That darkesome caue they enter, where they find
Arriued there, the dore they find fast lockt;
At last whenas himselfe he gan to find,
And there by force vnwonted passage find,
Whence mounting vp, they find purueyance meet
And shall find friends, if need requireth soe,
But if your selfe, Sir knight, ye faultie find,
There did I find, or rather I was found
Ye shall him Archimago find, I ghesse,
The falsest man aliue; who tries shall find no lesse.
He may it find; ne let him then admire,
Where euer he that godly knight may find,
A pleasing vaine of glory vaine did find,
Both feare and hope he in her face did find,
Who seekes with painfull toile, shall honour soonest find.
That my engreeued mind could find no rest,
Trust me, shall find no greater enimy,
Yet in himselfe some comfort he did find,
When euer his fiers hands he free mote find:
Whom bold Cymochles trauelling to find,
Your yron brestes, or pittie could find place,
Yet no where can her find: such happinesse
That haue twelue moneths sought one, yet no where can her find.
Did in the gardins of Adonis find
Where she may find the substaunce thin and light,
'Mongst thousands good one wanton Dame to find:
Could find no rest in such perplexed plight,
Here haue I cause, in men iust blame to find,
But by record of antique times I find,
Of sundry things faire purpose gan to find,
And read, where I that faytour false may find.
(Said he) perhaps ye should it better find:
And sith it is vneath to find his haunt,
For which no reason can find remedy.
Ne can my running sore find remedie,
But this affection nothing straunge I find;
Short end of sorrowes they thereby did find;
To compasse thy desire, and find that loued knight.
Full many waies she sought, but none could find,
How shall she know, how shall she find the man?
Him such, as fittest she for loue could find,
But can ye read Sir, how I may her find, or where.
And haply in her hart find highest rowme,
To seeke his Lady, where he mote her find;
That seemed those two vertues stroue to find
Yet no'te she find redresse for such despight.
To find some refuge there, and rest her weary syde.
To find them out. Mote I (then laughing sayd
Would hardly find to aggrauate her griefe;
To find him forth: and after her are gone
Vntill that it an issew forth may find;
Cannot two fairer Cities find this day,
A fit occasion for his turne to find:
For he was much affraid, himselfe alone to find.
In beastly vse that I did euer find;
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
If good find grace, and righteousnesse reward,
Yet could not find what sence it figured:
Shall find, that all the workes of those wise sages,
That shall you win more glory, then ye here find gaines.
Cannot find one this girdle to inuest.
Did find it fit, withouten breach or let.
But no where could her find, nor tydings of her heare.
Till I her find, and wreake on him that her did reaue.
And new occasion fayld her more to find,
For in that place where I him thought to find,
All vnawares the bird, when she did find
Where was her won, and how he mote her find.
Shall in this storie find approued plaine;
There he did find in her delitious boure
But there mote find to please it selfe withall;
Whom she besought to find some remedie:
Ne could by search nor any meanes out find
Through his disease, did by and by out find,
Shall find that from the point, where they first tooke
Vpon wyld beasts, which she in woods did find,
The greater prowesse greater perils find.
That all astonisht he him selfe did find,
What right is it, that he should thraldome find,
For I him find to be too proudly fed.
Ne euer did deceiptfull Clarin find
There looking forth, shee in her heart did find
But will my cares vnfolde, in hope to find
Should issue forth, in hope to find some spoyle,
Yet could the Seneschals no entrance find
Ne ought to answere thereunto did find;
Ne none can find, but who was taught them by the Muse.
To find him out, yet still I forward trace.
And in the eyes of men great liking find;
Tooke in foule scorne, that I such fault did find,
But when as her he by no meanes could find,
Find remedie vnsought, which seeking cannot fynd.
To worke by wicked treason wayes doth find,
Whom by the Altar he doth sitting find,
He thus replyde; Now surely syre, I find,
Ne him could find to fancie in her brest:
There did they find, that which they did not feare,
There did they find, contrarie to their thought,
They cannot finde that path, which first was showne,
Till that some end they finde or in or out,
There they do finde that godly aged Sire,
That auncient Lord gan fit occasion finde,
To finde some issue thence, till that at last
And hard to finde, that heat of youthfull spright
There did I finde mine onely faithfull frend
Such oddes I finde twixt those, and these which are,
Long they her sought, yet no where could they finde her,
Great threasure sithence we did finde contained;
In case she might finde fauour in his eye,
And armes had borne, but little good could finde,
The better to beguile, whom she so fond did finde.
So faire a patterne finde, where may be seene
Finde fauour to be lodged there for that same night.
Let me therefore this fauour for him finde,
Finde harbour fit to comfort her great neede.
Where when all drownd in deadly sleepe he findes,
In drowsie fit he findes: of nothing he takes keepe.
She findes forth comming from her darkesome mew,
Findes Mordant and Amauia slaine
His owne woes authour, who so bound it findes,
Guyon findes Mammon in a delue,
Findes emongst Satyres, whence with him
Fond is the feare, that findes no remedie;
findes Scudamour distrest:
Gainst which the pallid death findes no defence.
Whose double gates he findeth locked fast,
And findeth dew effect or soone or late.
Came forth, and finding Kirkrapine there slaine,
Th'enchaunter finding fit for his intents,
He that braue steed there finding ready dight,
Where finding life not yet dislodged quight,
Finding in it fit ports for fishers trade,
Finding the Nymph a sleepe in secret wheare,
Who finding litle leasure her to wooe,
And finding not th'Hyena to be slaine,
And finding him vnable once to weld,
Where finding that the breath gan him to fayle,
